questions.text: A child presented with complaints of itching and discharges on flexure aspect of elbow and the lesions were red as shown below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atopic dermatitis

 

The most likely diagnosis for the case presented is atopic dermatitis, a common inflammatory skin condition often associated with the atopic state, which includes eczema, asthma, and allergic rhinitis. This condition is characterized by impaired epidermal barrier function, often due to a genetic predisposition. In many patients, a mutation in the filaggrin gene is responsible for this barrier defect.

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with:

 

  • Eczematous lesions: These lesions are often red, inflamed, and may ooze or become crusted. They frequently occur in flexural areas such as the elbows, knees, and neck.
  • Pruritus (itching): Intense itching is a hallmark of atopic dermatitis, often leading to scratching that can exacerbate the lesions.
  • Chronic course: The condition usually has a chronic course with periods of exacerbation and remission. Lesions often persist for more than 6 weeks.
  • Family history: There is often a personal or family history of atopic conditions, including asthma, allergic rhinitis, or food allergies.
  • Lichenification: Chronic scratching may lead to thickened, leathery skin, known as lichenification.

 

The clinical image provided shows red, excoriated lesions in the flexure aspect of the elbow, which is highly characteristic of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus vulgaris: This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that typically presents with flaccid blisters and erosions on the skin and mucous membranes, not with the eczematous lesions seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option B. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically presents with well-demarcated, thick, silvery scales on extensor surfaces like the elbows and knees. It is not associated with the flexural distribution or the intense pruritus seen in atopic dermatitis.

 

Option C. Post-traumatic pigmentation: This refers to skin discoloration following an injury. It does not present with eczematous lesions or intense itching, and it is not limited to flexural areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atopic dermatitis typically presents with pruritic, eczematous lesions on flexural areas, often associated with a personal or family history of atopy.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine

 

Urine is the best sample to send for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus infection among the following options.

 

CMV can be detected using either PCR or culture. Saliva, urine, or blood can be used to collect the sample.

 

  • Clinical features:
    1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
    2. Prematurity
    3. Microcephaly
    4. Intracranial calcifications (Periventricular)
    5. Chorioretinitis
    6. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
    7. Hepatosplenomegaly
    8. Jaundice
    9. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
    10. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
    11. Mild increases in CSF protein

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver biopsy: In any of the TORCH infection, liver biopsy is not the investigation of choice. Live biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option B. CSF: In case of suspected meningitis we do CSF, not in TORCH profile

 

Option C. Blood: In this question blood sample is not the right option. If the question was regarding diagnosing of congenital varicella infection, then the right choice would be ANTI – VZV – ANTIBODY

 

Educational Objective:


Urine is the most appropriate sample for the detection of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection using PCR, particularly in the neonatal period.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movement of limbs towards the body. On examination, there is a regression of developmental milestones. Electroencephalogram shows hypsarrhythmia. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)

 

The clinical presentation and EEG findings are consistent with infantile spasms, which is seen in WEST Syndrome. The drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in WEST syndrome is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Drug of choice of baby with infantile spasms in tuberous sclerosis is vigabtrin.

 

Infantile spasms typically present as clusters of sudden, brief, symmetric, and often flexor or extensor jerks of the limbs or trunk. The spasms are usually associated with regression of developmental milestones, including loss of acquired skills such as smiling, babbling, or sitting up. Hypsarrhythmia, which is a chaotic and disorganized pattern of high-amplitude, asynchronous spikes and slow waves on EEG, is a characteristic finding in infantile spasms.

 

ACTH is the most effective medication for the treatment of infantile spasms. It is believed to work by decreasing the inflammation and abnormal electrical activity in the brain that is thought to be responsible for the spasms. ACTH is typically administered as a daily injection, usually for a duration of several weeks. The response to treatment is usually monitored with serial EEGs, which should show improvement in the hypsarrhythmia pattern.

 

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:

 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is the second line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not typically used for treating infantile spasms associated with West Syndrome.

 

Option C. Levetiracetam: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication but is not the first-line treatment for West Syndrome.

 

Option D. Phenobarbitone: Phenobarbitone is the first line of drug of choice in neonatal seizures but is not the preferred treatment for infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice for treating infantile spasms in West Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following medications taken during pregnancy is associated with the birth defect shown in the image? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Isotretinoin

 

Explanation:

 

The facial defects, including cleft lip, observed in the child are characteristic of the teratogenic effects of isotretinoin. Isotretinoin is commonly used to treat severe acne but is highly teratogenic and should never be prescribed to women of reproductive age without ensuring they are not pregnant. The teratogenic effects of isotretinoin include craniofacial, cardiovascular, thymic, and central nervous system abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferrous sulfate - This is an iron supplement and does not cause such birth defects.

 

Option C. Folic acid - This vitamin is actually recommended during pregnancy to prevent birth defects.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide - This antiemetic is not associated with the type of birth defects described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotretinoin, used for severe acne treatment, is highly teratogenic and associated with severe birth defects such as craniofacial abnormalities, including cleft lip and palate.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child arrived with a history of fever, reddened and congested conjunctiva, along with skin exhibiting redness and peeling, as depicted in the provided images. A 2D echocardiogram revealed the presence of a coronary aneurysm. What constitutes the initial course of treatment for this condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVIG

 

The clinical presentation of fever, congested conjunctiva, strawberry tongue, and red skin peeling, along with the echocardiogram finding of a coronary aneurysm, is highly suggestive of Kawasaki disease. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects children and can lead to coronary artery aneurysms if not treated promptly.

 

Initial Treatment: The mainstay of treatment for Kawasaki disease is the administration of Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG is given to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms, which is the most serious complication of Kawasaki disease. The standard dose is 2 g/kg administered as a single infusion, usually within the first 10 days of illness.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is also used in the management of Kawasaki disease, typically in conjunction with IVIG. However, IVIG is the first-line treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent coronary complications.

 

Option C. Clopidogrel: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent, but it is not part of the initial treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option D. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is an anticoagulant, but it is not used as the primary treatment for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In Kawasaki disease, the initial course of treatment involves the administration of IVIG to reduce the risk of coronary artery aneurysms and other complications.

questions.text: How long should a child be isolated after being diagnosed with bacterial meningitis to prevent further transmission? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Till 24 hours after starting antibiotics

 

The recommended duration for isolation in cases of bacterial meningitis is until 24 hours after the initiation of effective antibiotic therapy. This is crucial for preventing the spread of infections caused by organisms such as Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). After 24 hours of effective treatment, the risk of transmission significantly decreases, allowing the patient to be removed from isolation.

 

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

 

  • Standard precautions should be implemented for all patients admitted with meningitis.
  • Patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Hib meningitis should be placed on droplet precautions until they have received 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy.
  • Patients with these infections should be placed in private rooms during this isolation period.
  • Hospital personnel should wear a face mask when within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Till cultures become negative: This is not a practical or recommended criterion for lifting isolation because cultures can take several days to become negative, and the patient is not typically contagious after 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option C. Till antibiotic course is complete: The full course of antibiotics may last 7-14 days, during which time isolation is not necessary after the first 24 hours of effective treatment.

 

Option D. Till 12 hours after admission: This is incorrect as it does not meet the standard infection control guidelines. The 24-hour mark after starting effective antibiotics is the critical time point for lifting isolation.

 

Educational Objective:


Children with bacterial meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis or Haemophilus influenzae should be isolated for 24 hours after starting effective antibiotic therapy to prevent transmission.

questions.text: Causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis are all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ABO incompatibility

 

  • ABO incompatibility is an immune-mediated cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn, but it is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Non-immune hydrops is often caused by factors other than immune reactions, such as congenital heart defects, infections, or chromosomal anomalies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congestive cardiac failure: Congestive cardiac failure can contribute to non-immune hydrops fetalis. Conditions affecting the fetal heart can lead to fluid accumulation, resulting in hydrops.

 

Option C. Parvovirus infection: Parvovirus infection is a known cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Parvovirus can affect the developing fetus and lead to severe anemia, causing fluid accumulation.

 

Option D. Chromosomal anomalies: Chromosomal anomalies, such as Turner syndrome or trisomy 21, are associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis. Abnormalities in fetal development, including those affecting multiple organ systems, can lead to fluid accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the various causes of non-immune hydrops fetalis. Understand that conditions such as congestive cardiac failure, infections (e.g., parvovirus), and chromosomal anomalies can contribute to the development of hydrops in the absence of immune-mediated factors. Be aware that ABO incompatibility is not a typical cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: Surgical correction of VSD is performed in an infant. This will help in relieving which of the following features? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Failure to thrive.

 

Surgical correction of a Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) primarily helps in relieving the symptoms of congestive heart failure, which often manifest as failure to thrive in infants. Infants with VSD may experience poor weight gain, difficulty feeding, excessive sweating, irritability, and signs of respiratory distress such as tachypnea and labored breathing. These symptoms arise because the left-to-right shunt created by the VSD increases pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary overcirculation and congestive heart failure. Surgical intervention closes the defect, thereby normalizing blood flow and alleviating the symptoms of heart failure, allowing the infant to grow and thrive normally.

 

The key indications for VSD surgery include:

 

  • Large defects associated with pulmonary hypertension.
  • Qp ratio greater than 2:1 (indicating a significant left-to-right shunt).
  • Supracristal VSD, which carries a risk of aortic valve involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory alkalosis: Respiratory alkalosis is not typically associated with VSD. VSD primarily affects the heart and pulmonary circulation rather than directly causing changes in the acid-base balance.

 

Option C. Arrhythmia: Arrhythmias in infants are usually related to electrolyte imbalances or other cardiac conditions, but not directly to VSD. Surgical correction of VSD is aimed at correcting the structural defect, not managing arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Heart block: Heart block is a conduction issue in the heart and is not a feature directly caused by VSD. VSD surgery does not specifically address heart block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical correction of VSD in infants primarily helps relieve congestive heart failure symptoms, particularly failure to thrive, by normalizing pulmonary blood flow.

choices.text: Tetralogy of Fallot
Transposition of the Great Arteries
Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and poor feeding. On physical examination, the infant shows signs of tachypnea and tachycardia. An echocardiogram is performed, which reveals abnormal venous return of the pulmonary veins, with no direct connection to the left atrium. Further evaluation indicates equal oxygen saturation in all four chambers of the heart. Which of the following congenital heart diseases is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC)

 

Explanation:


Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, oxygenated blood from the lungs is redirected to the right atrium via connections to the superior vena cava, inferior vena cava, or both. This leads to a total mixing lesion where both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood mix completely, resulting in equal oxygen saturation in all four heart chambers. Blood reaches the left atrium and subsequently the left ventricle only through an atrial septal defect (ASD) or a patent foramen ovale, which shunts the mixed blood from the right atrium. This unique feature of TAPVC results in the characteristic finding of equal oxygen saturation in all cardiac chambers. TAPVC often presents with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and poor feeding in neonates and requires urgent surgical correction to restore normal pulmonary venous return.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Tetralogy of Fallot: This defect involves right ventricular outflow obstruction, a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It results in cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting but does not cause equal saturation in all chambers.

 

Option B) Transposition of the Great Arteries: This condition features parallel circulations with the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle, leading to severe cyanosis without equal saturation across all chambers.

 

Option D) Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A VSD allows for shunting of blood between the ventricles, but it does not cause equal oxygen saturation in all heart chambers.

 

Educational Objective:


TAPVC is a congenital heart defect that leads to equal oxygen saturation in all heart chambers due to the abnormal drainage of pulmonary veins into the right atrium, causing complete mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. Early diagnosis and surgical intervention are crucial to reestablish normal pulmonary venous return and prevent complications.

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with a body weight of 15kg and height of 100cm is admitted with renal failure. His blood urea was 100 mg/dL and serum creatinine was 1 mg/dL. What is the closest calculated eGFR in the patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 40 ml/min/1.73 m2 BSA

 

Step-by-Step Calculation

 

Step 1: Identify the appropriate k value

For a 4-year-old child: k = 0.413

 

Step 2: Apply the formula

eGFR = k × Height / Serum Creatinine

 

Step 3: Substitute values

eGFR = 0.413 × 100 / 1

 

Step 4: Calculate

eGFR = 41.3 / 1 = 41.3 ml/min/1.73 m²

 

Step 5: Round to nearest option

41.3 ≈ 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in pediatric patients can be calculated using the Schwartz formula, which is widely used in clinical practice. The formula takes into account the patient's height and serum creatinine levels, along with a constant value that is adjusted for age and sex.

 

The modified Schwartz formula is most commonly used for this purpose. It is given as:

 

 

 

For children aged 1 to 16 years, the constant k is typically 0.413

 

Given the child's height of 100 cm and serum creatinine of 1 mg/dL:

 

 

 

The closest value provided in the options is 40 ml/min/1.73 m² BSA, which is therefore the correct answer

 

Understand and apply the Schwartz formula for estimating eGFR in pediatric patients based on height and serum creatinine levels.

questions.text: A male child with coarse facies, macroglossia, thick lips with hepatosplenomegaly presents with copious mucous discharge from the nose. The most probable underlying diagnosis is? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hurler disease.

 

The clinical presentation described, including coarse facial features, macroglossia (enlarged tongue), thick lips, hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and copious mucus discharge from the nose, is characteristic of Hurler disease. Hurler disease is a severe form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1 (MPS 1), which results from a deficiency in the enzyme alpha-L-iduronidase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans, specifically heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, in various tissues.

 

Key Clinical Features of Hurler Disease:

 

  • Coarse facial features: The facial appearance is often described as "gargoyle-like" due to the thickening of facial structures.
  • Macroglossia and thick lips: Enlargement of the tongue and thickened lips are common in Hurler disease.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is a typical finding.
  • Corneal clouding: Although not mentioned in the question, this is another characteristic finding in Hurler disease.
  • Skeletal abnormalities: These include joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.
  • Upper respiratory tract involvement: Patients may experience recurrent respiratory infections, noisy breathing, and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: This is an overgrowth syndrome characterized by features such as macrosomia (large body size), macroglossia, hemihypertrophy (asymmetrical body growth), omphalocele (abdominal wall defect), and an increased risk of certain cancers like Wilms tumor and hepatoblastoma. However, the combination of features presented in this case aligns more closely with Hurler disease.

 

Option C. Proteus Syndrome: This is a rare condition characterized by overgrowth of bones, skin, and other tissues. It does not typically present with the features described in the question, such as coarse facies, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious mucus discharge.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: While congenital hypothyroidism can present with macroglossia and coarse facial features, it typically does not cause the combination of symptoms described in this case, such as hepatosplenomegaly and persistent nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hurler disease, a form of mucopolysaccharidosis type 1, presents with coarse facial features, macroglossia, hepatosplenomegaly, and copious nasal discharge, and is caused by a deficiency in alpha-L-iduronidase leading to the accumulation of glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text:
How would you manage a child with status epilepticus? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Airway and breathing
  2. IV Lorazepam
  3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone
  4. IV Fosphenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4, 3

 

Status epilepticus is defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness.

 

Status epilepticus is a neurological emergency defined as continuous or recurrent seizure activity lasting for more than 5 minutes without regaining consciousness between episodes. Prompt and systematic management is essential to prevent long-term neurological damage or death.

 

Management Sequence:

 

1. Airway and Breathing: The first priority is to ensure that the airway is open and that the child is breathing adequately. This may involve positioning the child, providing oxygen, and, if necessary, securing the airway with advanced airway management techniques.

 

2. IV Lorazepam: Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the first-line treatment for status epilepticus due to their rapid onset of action and effectiveness in terminating seizures. Lorazepam is typically administered intravenously.

 

4. IV Fosphenytoin: If seizures continue after the administration of a benzodiazepine, IV fosphenytoin (or phenytoin) is used as a second-line agent. It helps to stabilize neuronal membranes and prevent further seizure activity.

 

3. Midazolam, Propofol, Thiopentone: These agents are used if seizures persist despite initial treatments. Midazolam can be administered intramuscularly or intravenously, while propofol and thiopentone are typically reserved for refractory status epilepticus and may require the child to be in an intensive care setting due to the need for mechanical ventilation and close monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of status epilepticus in children should follow a systematic approach: securing the airway and ensuring breathing, administering a benzodiazepine, followed by fosphenytoin if seizures persist, and considering more potent agents like midazolam, propofol, or thiopentone if the status epilepticus is refractory to initial treatments.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The clinical scenario of a child with resistant rickets and the following laboratory findings—normal serum calcium, normal parathyroid hormone, decreased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, increased urinary phosphate, decreased urinary calcium, and normal ABG and serum creatinine—is highly suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets: This condition is characterized by low serum phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, leading to rickets despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D. It is often caused by mutations affecting phosphate-regulating genes like PHEX.
  • Laboratory Findings: The hallmark of this condition includes low serum phosphate, high alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D dependent rickets: This would typically show low calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone levels due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or action. Serum phosphate may also be low, but the distinguishing factor is the response to vitamin D therapy, which is absent in hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition usually presents with low calcium and high phosphate levels due to insufficient parathyroid hormone. The given case has normal calcium and low phosphate, making hypoparathyroidism unlikely.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: This would typically show elevated serum creatinine along with abnormalities in calcium and phosphate metabolism. The normal creatinine level in this patient rules out chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids.

 

In the management of severe COVID-19 in children, corticosteroids are the primary treatment among the given options. Corticosteroids are recommended for children with severe cases, which include conditions like acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe pneumonia, septic shock, and multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).

 

Severe COVID-19 is characterized by symptoms such as SpO2 less than 90% on room air, severe chest retractions, grunting, lethargy, and signs of pneumonia with cyanosis. In these cases, corticosteroids like Dexamethasone or Methylprednisolone are used to reduce inflammation and manage the severe immune response associated with the virus.

 

Guidelines for Steroid Use in Severe COVID-19:

 

  • Indications: Corticosteroids are indicated in rapidly progressive moderate cases and all severe cases. They are generally avoided in the first 3-5 days of illness due to the risk of increased viral shedding during this period.
  • Dosage: Dexamethasone is given at a dose of 0.15 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 6 mg once a day, or Methylprednisolone at 0.75 mg/kg with a maximum dose of 30 mg once a day.
  • Duration: The treatment typically continues for 5-6 days and then is tapered off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is not recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children. Ivermectin has been used for deworming, not for treating COVID-19.

 

Option C. Remdesivir: Remdesivir is an antiviral medication used in some hospitalized patients with mild to moderate COVID-19 but is not the primary treatment for severe cases in children. It inhibits viral replication by terminating RNA transcription prematurely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids are recommended for the treatment of severe COVID-19 in children to manage inflammation and the severe immune response associated with the virus.

questions.text: A child presents with brown-colored urine and oliguria for the last 3 days. He has mild facial and pedal edema. His blood pressure is 126/90. He has 2+ proteinuria with >100 red cells/HPF and a few granular casts. His creatinine is 0.9, urea is 56. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PSGN

 

  • The clinical picture points to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. (PSGN).
  • PSGN is characterised by sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency.
  • Most children recover entirely from hematuria and proteinuria within 3-6 weeks of the beginning of nephritis after a throat infection with nephritogenic strains of group A -hemolytic streptococci. However, between 3 and 10% of children may have persistent microscopic hematuria, non-nephrotic proteinuria, or hypertension.

 

Light microscopy reveals larger, pale glomeruli with diffuse mesangial proliferation and an increase in the mesangial matrix in PSGN. In the early stages, polymorph neutrophils (PMN) infiltrate.

 

Immunofluorescence: "Lumpy-bumpy" IgG and complement deposits on the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and

 

Electron microscopy- humps are seen on epithelial side of glomerular basement membrane

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrolithiasis: Nephrolithiasis will have features of kidney stones in ultrasound. Symptoms: dysuria, hypogastric pain, hematuria & repeated urinary infections.

 

Option C. Posterior Urethral Valve: this is one of the cause of distal urinary tract obstruction in boys. Clinical features, abnormal urinary stream, dribbling, palpable bladder & recurrent UTI.

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: Blood pressure of the patient will be normal. Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency are indicative of PSGN.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structure is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

The structure marked as 2 represents Type II pneumocytes, which are crucial in the pathophysiology of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

 

Key Points:

 

  • Type I pneumocytes (Marked as 1): These cells are large and flattened, making up the majority of the alveolar surface area. They form the thin barrier necessary for efficient gas exchange.
  • Type II pneumocytes (Marked as 2): These cells are rounded and responsible for producing surfactant, a substance composed of phospholipids and proteins that reduces surface tension within the alveoli. Surfactant is essential for preventing alveolar collapse (atelectasis) during exhalation. In respiratory distress syndrome, especially in premature infants, the deficiency or dysfunction of these Type II cells leads to insufficient surfactant production, causing the alveoli to collapse and resulting in severe breathing difficulties.
  • Endothelial cells of capillaries (Marked as 3): These cells line the blood vessels within the lungs and are involved in the exchange of gases between the blood and alveoli. They are not primarily involved in the pathogenesis of RDS.
  • Red Blood Cells (Marked as 4): These are the cells responsible for carrying oxygen from the lungs to the rest of the body and returning carbon dioxide to the lungs for exhalation. While essential for overall respiratory function, they are not the site of damage in RDS.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

  • Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS): Commonly seen in premature infants, RDS is primarily caused by a deficiency of surfactant due to immature Type II pneumocytes. The lack of surfactant leads to increased surface tension, alveolar collapse, and severe respiratory distress. This condition is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality in preterm infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type II pneumocytes are crucial for surfactant production and alveolar stability, and their dysfunction or immaturity is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in neonates.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with leg pain. She had fever and cough 3 days prior. Currently, there is pain on palpation of the calf muscles. Reflexes and other clinical examinations are normal. Lab test reveals CK levels of 2000 IU. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Viral myositis

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with viral myositis. Viral myositis is an inflammation of the muscles caused by viral infection, often following an upper respiratory tract illness. The condition is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Recent viral illness: The history of fever and cough 3 days prior suggests a preceding viral infection, which is a common trigger for viral myositis.
  • Leg pain and muscle tenderness: Viral myositis often presents with significant muscle soreness, especially in the calf muscles, leading to pain on palpation.
  • Elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels: The CK level of 2000 IU indicates muscle injury or inflammation, which is consistent with viral myositis.
  • Normal reflexes and neurological examination: This helps differentiate viral myositis from other conditions like Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) or Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which would typically present with abnormal reflexes or progressive muscle weakness.

 

Influenza is a common viral cause of myositis, particularly in children. The muscle pain typically begins 1-7 days after the onset of the viral illness and may lead to difficulty walking, often with a characteristic toe-walking gait due to involvement of the gastrocnemius-soleus muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is a genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness, typically presenting with proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, and elevated CK levels. However, it does not present acutely following a viral illness and usually starts earlier in life.

 

Option C. GBS (Guillain-Barré Syndrome): GBS is an autoimmune condition that causes ascending paralysis, starting with weakness in the legs. Reflexes are usually diminished or absent in GBS, unlike the normal reflexes observed in this case.

 

Option D. Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory muscle disease characterized by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. It usually presents with chronic, progressive weakness rather than acute pain following a viral illness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viral myositis is characterized by muscle pain, especially in the calves, following a viral infection, with elevated CK levels and normal reflexes, distinguishing it from other neuromuscular conditions.

questions.text: Phototherapy converts bilirubin to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lumirubin

 

Phototherapy is a standard treatment for neonatal jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia. The primary purpose of phototherapy is to reduce elevated bilirubin levels in the blood by converting the toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a form that can be more easily excreted by the body.

 

Mechanisms involved in phototherapy:

 

  1. Irreversible Structural Isomerization: This is the most important mechanism of phototherapy. It converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a more water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys in an unconjugated form. Lumirubin is more easily excreted in the urine, reducing serum bilirubin levels.
  2. Reversible Photo-isomerization Reaction: This process converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into a non-toxic configurational isomer, which can be excreted in the bile without conjugation.
  3. Photo-oxidation: This is a minor mechanism where bilirubin undergoes oxidation to form colorless products that are also excreted.

 

Contraindications: Phototherapy is contraindicated in conditions like porphyria, where exposure to light can cause severe photosensitivity and blistering.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stercobilin: This is a bile pigment formed from the breakdown of bilirubin in the intestines, giving stool its characteristic brown color. It is not directly involved in the process of phototherapy.

 

Option C. Biliverdin: Biliverdin is a precursor to bilirubin in the heme breakdown pathway. Phototherapy does not convert bilirubin back to biliverdin.

 

Option D. Urobilin: Urobilin is a product of bilirubin metabolism that is excreted in the urine, giving urine its yellow color. It is not the primary product of phototherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phototherapy converts bilirubin into lumirubin, a water-soluble isomer that can be excreted by the kidneys, making it an effective treatment for neonatal jaundice.

choices.text: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

questions.text: Palivizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody. For which condition is it approved? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

 

Explanation:

 

Palivizumab is specifically approved for the prevention and treatment of respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections. It is particularly recommended for infants at high risk, such as those born prematurely or with conditions like congenital heart disease or chronic lung disease. Palivizumab works by providing passive immunity against RSV, reducing the severity and incidence of RSV-related illnesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avian influenza - Palivizumab is not used for treating or preventing avian influenza.

 

Option B. Parainfluenza - Palivizumab is not indicated for parainfluenza infections.

 

Option D. Coxsackie virus - Palivizumab is not used for Coxsackie virus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palivizumab is approved for preventing and treating respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infections in high-risk infants.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

The clinical presentation of a swollen belly and dull face in a child fed mostly rice water, along with findings of low serum protein and low albumin, is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by:

 

  • Edema: Resulting from hypoalbuminemia, which leads to fluid retention and swelling, especially in the abdomen.
  • Apathy and irritability: The child often appears listless and irritable.
  • Poor diet history: Often associated with diets low in protein, such as those predominantly consisting of carbohydrates like rice water.
  • Other symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle wasting, and skin and hair changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe acute malnutrition but is characterized by severe wasting and absence of edema. Children with marasmus appear extremely thin with prominent ribs and have a "skin and bones" appearance.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This is a chronic liver disease in children characterized by liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the acute signs of protein malnutrition like Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: This is an acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children under 5 years of age and involves inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). It does not present with symptoms of malnutrition such as a swollen belly due to low protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

choices.text: To be done in lateral recumbent position
The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle.

questions.text: Regarding the procedure done with the needle shown below, which of the following is false? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coagulopathy is not a contraindication.

 

The image depicts a spinal needle used primarily for lumbar puncture (LP), a procedure where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected from the lumbar cistern. The procedure can be conducted in either the lateral recumbent position or sitting position, depending on the patient's comfort and the physician's preference. The bevel orientation during insertion affects the dural fibers; positioning it parallel (typically upwards) minimizes dural fiber tearing and the subsequent likelihood of post-lumbar puncture headaches. Importantly, coagulopathy is a significant contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the increased risk of spinal hematoma and severe complications associated with bleeding around the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To be done in lateral recumbent position: This is true and is one of the standard positions for performing an LP.

 

Option B. Breath holding is not necessary: During LP, patients are advised to breathe normally to avoid increases in intra-abdominal and intrathoracic pressure, which could affect CSF dynamics.

 

Option C. The bevel should face upwards while inserting the needle: This is a recommended practice to reduce the risk of post-procedure complications, such as a post-dural puncture headache.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coagulopathy is a contraindication for lumbar puncture due to the risk of bleeding and potential for serious complications, contrary to the incorrect statement provided. Always assess the patient’s coagulation status prior to performing an LP.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby is brought to OPD with jaundice and clay-colored stools. Lab work up reveals that the baby has conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A liver biopsy was done and shows periductal proliferation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Biliary atresia

 

An infant with jaundice, clay-coloured stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

 

An infant with Biliary atresia presents with progressive jaundice, persistent yellow stools, and palpable liver with abnormal consistency.

 

Laboratory investigations show conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Ultrasonography reveals a triangular-cord sign (cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein).

 

HIDA test is more relevant for its negative predictive value (100%). Liver biopsy is diagnostic for biliary atresia. In biliary atresia, portal tract expansion, ductular proliferation and fibrosis is seen.

 

Laparotomy and perioperative cholangiography may be required in an infant with equivocal biopsy, findings and no excretion on HIDA scan, to evaluate for biliary atresia.

 

Biliary atresia is managed by Kasai procedure (hepato-portoenterostomy).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: This is characterized by absent or deficient UGT enzyme leading to increased unconjugated bilirubin. It does not present with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia or clay-colored stools.

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: A mild form of Dubin-Johnson syndrome that causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, but without the dark liver appearance seen in Dubin-Johnson syndrome. It does not present with periductal proliferation on liver biopsy.

 

Option C. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Characterized by increased conjugated bilirubin and a dark liver appearance. It is an autosomal recessive disorder but does not present with the same liver biopsy findings as biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An infant presenting with jaundice, clay-colored stools, and periductal proliferation on liver biopsy is highly suggestive of biliary atresia.

questions.text: Which of the following immunodeficiency disorders has a high chance of catalase positive organisms causing infections?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex. This defect impairs the ability of phagocytes to produce reactive oxygen species, which are crucial for killing certain bacteria and fungi. As a result, individuals with CGD are particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms, which can neutralize hydrogen peroxide and thus evade destruction by the impaired phagocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyper IgE syndrome: Also known as Job syndrome, this disorder is characterized by high levels of IgE, recurrent skin abscesses, pneumonia, and characteristic facial features. It is not specifically associated with increased infections by catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option C. Bruton disease: Also known as X-linked agammaglobulinemia, this condition affects B cell development, leading to low levels of immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, but not specifically to catalase-positive organisms.

 

Option D. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome: This is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and immunodeficiency. While patients have an increased risk of infections, the susceptibility to catalase-positive organisms is not as pronounced as in CGD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease is associated with a high risk of infections by catalase-positive organisms due to a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex, which impairs the killing of these organisms by phagocytes.

questions.text: Dr. Sunita, a medical officer in a rural health clinic, is tasked with ensuring the potency and safety of vaccines. She comes across several vaccine vials, each with a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) attached. The VVMs change color to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat, thus helping in determining the viability of the vaccine. She notices varying degrees of color changes across these VVMs. Given this scenario, which of the following choices correctly identifies which vaccine vials, based on the observed VVM color changes, should be considered safe for use? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vials 1 and 2 can be used

 

  • Based on the image provided, it's evident that only vials 1 and 2 are suitable for use because the inner squares of these vials color lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male child presented with arthralgia and abdominal pain. On examination, there was palpable purpura over the lower limbs. There is a past history of upper respiratory tract infection prior to the onset of presenting symptoms. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucocorticoids

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein's purpura (HSP). Glucocorticoids are used to treat HSP.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant that may be used in severe cases of HSP with nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for the initial presentation of HSP.

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is used in various autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, but it is not typically used for the treatment of HSP.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive agent used in certain conditions, including severe nephritis, but it is not the first-line treatment for HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), particularly with significant gastrointestinal involvement or severe symptoms, is glucocorticoids such as prednisolone.

questions.text: A 12-day-old neonate presents to the emergency department with increased irritability, poor feeding, and two episodes of seizures. Physical examination reveals a bulging fontanelle and lethargy. A lumbar puncture shows elevated white blood cells, high protein, and low glucose, suggestive of bacterial meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal meningitis is suspected in this clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus), which is the leading cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis. It commonly affects both early-onset (within the first 72 hours of life) and late-onset neonatal infections.

 

Early-onset meningitis occurs within the first 72 hours of life and is mainly caused by Group B streptococci. In contrast, late-onset meningitis typically affects premature infants and is often caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci, such as Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Klebsiella.

 

Group B streptococci are the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis in full-term infants. Escherichia coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis in very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g), but it is less common than Group B streptococcus in full-term infants.

 

Neonates have immature cellular and humoral immunity, making them more susceptible to infections like meningitis and sepsis. Any infant aged 28 days or younger with fever or signs of sepsis should be promptly evaluated.

 

The evaluation for sepsis includes a complete blood count (CBC), differential count, blood culture, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture. These tests help identify the causative organism and determine appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Escherichia coli: Although a common cause of neonatal meningitis, especially in preterm and very low birth weight infants, it is less frequent in full-term infants compared to Group B streptococcus.

 

Option C) Staphylococcus aureus: Typically associated with late-onset infections, particularly in hospitalized infants or those with central lines, but not as common in the early neonatal period.

 

Option D) Listeria monocytogenes: A less common cause of neonatal meningitis, often linked to maternal risk factors, such as consumption of contaminated food, and not the most likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) is the primary cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, particularly in full-term infants. Due to the neonate’s immature immune system, early recognition and management of these infections are crucial to prevent severe complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Downs syndrome?  (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caudal regression syndrome

 

  • Caudal regression syndrome is not typically associated with Down syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is a congenital disorder characterized by abnormal development of the lower spine (caudal region). It is a separate condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism is a known association with Down syndrome. 

 

Option B. Hearing loss: Hearing loss is commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Ear infections and structural abnormalities may contribute to this condition.

 

Option C. Short stature: Short stature is a characteristic feature of Down syndrome. Individuals with Down syndrome often have a shorter stature compared to the general population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the common clinical features and associated conditions of Down syndrome. Understand that hypothyroidism, hearing loss, and short stature are commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome. Be aware of the distinct features of other congenital conditions, such as caudal regression syndrome, that are not typically associated with Down syndrome.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laryngeal papilloma

 

The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

 

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

 

  • Juvenile papillomatosis is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is viral in origin and is caused by human papilloma virus type 6 and 11.
  • It is presumed that affected children got the disease at birth from their mothers who had vaginal human papillomavirus disease.
  • Papilloma’s mostly affect supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx but can also involve subglottis, trachea and bronchi. DNA virus particles have been found in the cells of the basement membrane of respiratory mucosa and may account for widespread involvement and recurrence.
  • Patients, often a child, between the age of 3 and 5 years present with hoarseness or aphonia with respiratory difficulty or even stridor.
  • Diagnosis is made by flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy and later confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy.
  • Papillomas are known for recurrence but rarely undergo malignant change.
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision avoiding injury to vocal ligament. Other modalities of tumor removal are with cold steel instruments or  debrider or coblation or radiofrequency. Aim of therapy is to maintain a good airway, preserve voice and avoid recurrence.
  • Adjuvant medical therapies include Interferon alpha-2a and 13-cis-retinoic acid has been used.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Reinke's edema - Characterized by swelling of the vocal cords due to fluid accumulation, not similar to the warty growths of papillomas.

 

Option B. Malignancy - Would typically appear more irregular and could involve more invasive growth patterns.

 

Option C. Tracheomalacia - A condition related to the softening of the tracheal walls, not relevant to laryngeal lesions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Laryngeal papilloma is a significant pediatric condition caused by HPV, manifesting as benign, wart-like growths within the larynx. While these tumors are prone to recurrence, they rarely undergo malignant transformation, making careful ongoing monitoring and management essential.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 345

questions.text:
An unconscious child is brought to the casualty. What is the correct sequence of the management? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Assess breathing
  2. Assess pulse
  3. Assess response
  4. Start compressions
  5. Bag and mask ventilation
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3-1-2-4-5

 

When managing an unconscious child, especially in a potential cardiac or respiratory arrest scenario, it is crucial to follow the steps of Basic Life Support (BLS) in the correct sequence to ensure the best chance of recovery.

 

 

Sequence Justification:

 

  • The correct sequence is 3-1-2-4-5, which means:
    • 3: First, assess response (to determine unresponsiveness).
    • 1: Then assess breathing (to check for normal breathing).
    • 2: Followed by assessing the pulse (to check for circulation).
    • 4: Start compressions if necessary (if no pulse or poor perfusion).
    • 5: Provide bag and mask ventilation to support breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BLS, the correct sequence of actions is crucial for effective management. Start by assessing response, followed by breathing and pulse, then initiate compressions and ventilation as needed.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Minimal change disease

 

Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

On light microscopy, characteristic feature is no apparent abnormality in the glomeruli except for slight increase in the mesangial matrix at the most.

 

 

By electron microscopy, the most characteristic feature of the disease is identified which is diffuse flattening of foot processes of the visceral epithelial cells (podocytes) and, hence, the name foot process disease or podocytopathy.

 

In contrast to other types of GN, no deposits are visible, and the GBM is normal. No complement or immunoglobulin deposits are detected using immunofluorescence microscopy (nil deposit disease).

 

It's also seen in other diseases like membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. These diseases are also known as podocytopathies because they affect podocytes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Steroid resistant glomerulonephritis: This term is more of a clinical description rather than a specific pathological diagnosis. Steroid-resistant cases can include various glomerulonephritis types such as focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS), which also shows podocyte effacement but is not the classic example of it.

 

Option C. Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): RPGN is characterized by crescent formation in the glomeruli and is associated with severe glomerular damage and rapid loss of kidney function. It does not specifically show effacement of podocyte foot processes as its primary feature.

 

Option D. Chronic glomerulonephritis: Chronic glomerulonephritis encompasses various forms of long-standing glomerular diseases leading to chronic kidney damage. It is associated with glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis but not specifically with podocyte foot process effacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Effacement of podocyte foot processes is the characteristic feature of minimal change disease (MCD), which presents with nephrotic syndrome and shows normal glomeruli on light microscopy but diffuse foot process flattening on electron microscopy.

choices.text: Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm
Weight-for-length below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards
Weight-for-age below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards
Presence of bipedal edema

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with signs of malnutrition. The healthcare provider assesses the child’s nutritional status to determine if the child meets the criteria for severe acute malnutrition (SAM) according to WHO guidelines. Which of the following is not a criterion for diagnosing severe acute malnutrition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Weight-for-age below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards

 

Explanation:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is defined by the WHO based on specific criteria that assess acute malnutrition, focusing primarily on body measurements that reflect wasting and the presence of edema.

 

WHO Criteria for Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM):

 

  1. Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm: This measurement reflects wasting and is commonly used in the field to quickly assess nutritional status in children aged 6 to 59 months.
  2. Weight-for-length (or height) below -3 SD of the WHO child growth standards: This criterion specifically assesses the child’s weight relative to their height, indicating severe wasting.
  3. Presence of bipedal edema: Edema is a clinical sign of severe malnutrition, reflecting a more serious condition that is often associated with metabolic disturbances and increased risk of mortality.
  4. Weight-for-age below -3 SD: This is not a criterion for SAM. While weight-for-age can indicate undernutrition, it does not differentiate between stunting (chronic malnutrition) and wasting (acute malnutrition), making it less specific for diagnosing SAM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is diagnosed based on mid-upper arm circumference, weight-for-length or height below -3 SD, and the presence of bipedal edema. Weight-for-age is not used as a specific criterion for SAM because it does not accurately reflect acute malnutrition. Understanding these criteria is critical for identifying and managing malnutrition in pediatric populations.

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male came with complaints of persistent cough and weight loss. He has skin lesions as shown in the image. Chest x-ray showed multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates. His sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis was negative and he has a low CD4 count. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis

 

In this case, the patient presents with persistent cough, weight loss, and skin lesions. The chest x-ray reveals multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates, and the patient has a low CD4 count. These findings are significant for several reasons:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis can mimic tuberculosis, especially in HIV-positive patients. It causes disseminated disease with pulmonary involvement (multiple bilateral nodular infiltrates) and skin lesions. The presence of these lesions and a negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis further supports histoplasmosis, as this fungal infection is common in immunocompromised individuals with low CD4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HIV with disseminated cryptococcosis: While cryptococcosis can cause lung disease, it more commonly presents with central nervous system involvement, such as meningitis or meningoencephalitis. This patient does not exhibit neurological symptoms, making cryptococcosis less likely.

 

Option C. HIV with molluscum contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum causes umbilicated papules but does not lead to bilateral nodular infiltrates in the lungs. Thus, this diagnosis is unlikely given the chest x-ray findings.

 

Option D. HIV with tuberculosis: Tuberculosis is a common infection in HIV-positive patients and can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. However, the negative sputum CBNAAT for tuberculosis makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educaitonal Objective:

 

Disseminated histoplasmosis in HIV-positive patients can mimic tuberculosis, presenting with pulmonary nodular infiltrates and skin lesions, especially in those with low CD4 counts.

questions.text: Identify the vertebral level of section in given image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T9

 

The provided image shows a cross-sectional anatomy where key structures such as the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs are visible. At the T9 vertebral level, the liver and stomach are seen prominently, with the heart also visible, indicating that the section is at the level where these thoracic and upper abdominal structures overlap. The presence of the lungs further supports that this is a thoracic level.

 

 

 

Cross sectional anatomy of ABDOMEN:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T10: While the T10 level also shows some of the same structures, the visibility and position of the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs in this image are more indicative of T9.

 

Option C. T11: At the T11 level, the kidneys start to become visible, and the heart is usually not as prominent as it is at the T9 level.

 

Option D. T12: The T12 level typically shows the kidneys more clearly and does not include as much of the heart and upper liver as seen in the provided image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T9 vertebral level in cross-sectional anatomy images often shows the liver, stomach, heart, and lungs, making it a key point for identifying these structures.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

 

  • The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.
  • Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid-fast staining technique.

 

 

Option C: The image given below is of a gram-stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii.

 

 

Option D: The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing renal transplant management was started on cyclosporine as part of the immunosuppressive regimen. Within a few weeks, the patient begins to show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. The treating physician suspects drug-induced cholestasis and considers the involvement of a specific cellular transporter. Which cellular transporter is most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis in this patient
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRP2

 

  • MRP2, also known as Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2 or ABCC2, is a membrane-bound transporter protein that belongs to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family of transporters.
  • This protein is primarily expressed in the liver, particularly in the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, as well as in the kidneys, intestines, and other tissues.
  • MRP2 functions as an efflux pump, actively transporting a variety of substances out of cells including bile salts, bilirubin, glucuronides, and various drugs and their metabolites.
  • MRP2 plays a critical role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus. Mutations or inhibition of MRP2 (by drugs like cyclosporine) can lead to cholestasis, a condition where bile cannot flow from the liver to the duodenum.
  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is a genetic disorder resulting from mutations in the MRP2 gene, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MDR 1: Multi-Drug Resistance Protein 1 (MDR 1 or P-glycoprotein) is more known for its role in drug resistance, not specifically for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis. While MDR-1 plays a role in drug metabolism and can be inhibited by cyclosporine, it is generally not implicated in the development of drug-induced cholestasis, which is more closely associated with MRP2 inhibition.

 

Option B. BRCA: The Breast Cancer Susceptibility Gene (BRCA) is not related to drug metabolism or cholestasis. It is mainly involved in DNA repair and cancer susceptibility.

 

Option D. OATP1B1: Organic Anion Transporting Polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1) is involved in drug uptake into the liver but is not the key player in cyclosporine-induced cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRP2 (Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2) is the cellular transporter most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis due to its role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus.

questions.text: A young female has history of a induced abortion at 11 weeks. She has had amenorrhea since then. Her FSH now is 6 mlU/ml. Which of the following can be a cause for her amenorrhea? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

Explanation:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion and subsequent dilation and curettage (D&C) is typically due to intrauterine adhesions, also known as Asherman syndrome.

 

  • Uterine Synechiae (Asherman Syndrome): This condition involves the formation of scar tissue within the uterine cavity, leading to amenorrhea or menstrual abnormalities. It commonly occurs after uterine surgeries like D&C.
    • Diagnosis: Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman syndrome.
    • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the treatment to remove the adhesions and restore normal uterine cavity function.

Other options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: This would typically be associated with abnormal levels of pituitary hormones, including FSH. The normal FSH level (6 mIU/ml) suggests that pituitary function is intact.

 

Option B. Ovarian dysfunction: This condition would generally present with elevated or depressed levels of FSH and other ovarian hormones. The normal FSH level suggests that ovarian function is likely normal.

 

Option C. First pregnancy: In pregnancy, FSH levels are very low (<0.1 mIU/ml). The FSH level of 6 mIU/ml makes this an unlikely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary amenorrhea following a history of spontaneous abortion and D&C is usually due to intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), diagnosed by hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Which of the following anti-tubercular drug is not bactericidal? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thioacetazone

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug. Bacteriostatic drugs inhibit the growth and replication of bacteria, rather than killing them outright. Thioacetazone is less commonly used nowadays due to its side effects and the availability of more effective treatments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is a bactericidal drug against actively dividing Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the bacterial cell wall.

 

Option B. Rifapentin: Rifapentin is a bactericidal antibiotic and is a derivative of rifampicin. It works by inhibiting bacterial RNA synthesis and is used primarily in the treatment of tuberculosis.

 

Option D. Kanamycin: Kanamycin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic and is bactericidal. It works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is used as a second-line drug for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thioacetazone is a bacteriostatic anti-tubercular drug, which means it inhibits bacterial growth rather than killing the bacteria outright. In contrast, isoniazid, rifapentin, and kanamycin are all bactericidal drugs used in the treatment of tuberculosis.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PGE1

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) keeps the ductus arteriosus open (PDA). It is useful in maintaining the patency of the Ductus Arteriosus in term neonates who are awaiting surgical correction of underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease and having a duct dependent circulation.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. PGF2α: PGF2α (prostaglandin F2α) is involved in various physiological functions, including uterine contractions, but does not play a role in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option C. PGH2: PGH2 (prostaglandin H2) is a precursor in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway but does not directly maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. PGI2: PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation but is not specifically used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

 

Educational Objective

 

PGE1 (prostaglandin E1) is used to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus in neonates with congenital heart defects that require an open ductus arteriosus for adequate oxygenation and circulation.
